facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 1524, 1537-1580 of 1973, 74, 75, 254, 510-512 of 1970, 21 of 1971, and 1525, 1581-1606 of 1973 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 1524, 1537-1580 of 1973 and 74, 75, 254, 510-512 of 19702 21 of 1971 and 1525 1581-1606 of 1973. Petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: Petitioners are traders or commission agents dealing in agricultural produce

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners in all the above cases are traders or companymission agents dealing in agricultural produce. The following submissions are made on behalf of the petitioners The companystitution

facts.text: Validity of Uttar Pradesh Krishi Utpadhan Mandi Adhiniyam, 1964 (U.P. Act No. XXV of 1964) as amended by U.P. Act No. 10 of 1970 and rules thereunder challenged on grounds of violation of Article 14 and Article 19(1)(g)

anchor.surface_text: Goswami, J.-By the above writ applications under Article 32 of the Constitution the validity of the Uttar Pradesh Krishi Utpadhan Mandi Adhiniyam, 1964  U.P. Act No. XXV of 1964 as amended by U.P. Act No. 10 of 1970   briefly called the Act  and the rules made thereunder are challenged on the ground of violation of Article 14 and Article 19 1  g  of the, Constitution.

facts.text: Market Committee under section 13 of the Act consists of 23 members out of which 10 are from producers

anchor.surface_text: It is pointed out by the learned Solicitor General and number companytradicted by Mr. Sen that the Committee under section 13 companysists of 23 members out of which ten are from the producers.

facts.text: Petitioners claim constitution of Market Committee prejudicial due to perpetual majority of producers

anchor.surface_text: The companystitution of the Market Committee under section 13 of the Act is highly prejudicial to their interests and of the traders in general since, it will have a perpetual majority of producers.

facts.text: None of the petitioners have been refused a licence

anchor.surface_text: To say the least it is a hypothetical objection in this case, as, we understand, numbere of the petitioners have been refused a licence

facts.text: Act provides for regulation of sale and purchase of agricultural produce and establishment, superintendence, and control of markets in Uttar Pradesh

anchor.surface_text: Before we deal with these submissions, we may turn out attention to the Act. As the preamble shows the Act has to provide for the regulation of sale and purchase of agricultural produce and fox the establishment, superintendence, and companytrol of markets therefore in Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: Chaotic state of affairs in agricultural produce markets with innumerable charges, levies, exactions, disputes favoring buyers, manipulation of weights and scales

anchor.surface_text: The statement of object and reasons gives a clear picture of the evils sought to be, remedied by this legislation and a portion therefrom may be extracted below The present chaotic state of affairs as, obtaining in agricultural produce markets is an acknowledged fact. There are.,innumerable charges,, levies. and exactions which the agricultural producer is required to pay without having any say in the proper utilisation of the amount so paid by him.

facts.text: Legislation for regulation of markets recommended by Planning Commission to be enacted by 1955-56

anchor.surface_text: The Planning Commission stressed long ago that legislation in respect of regulation of markets should be, enacted and enforced by 1955-56.

facts.text: Agricultural produce defined in section 2(a) includes items of agriculture, horticulture etc. specified in schedule, admixtures, processed forms, gur, rab etc.

anchor.surface_text: By section 2 a  agricultural produce means such items of produce of agriculture, horticulture, viticulture, apiculture, sericulture, pisciculture, animal husbandry or forest as are specified in the schedule, and includes admixture of 2 or more of such items, and also includes any such item in processed form, and further includes gur, rab, shakkar, khandsari and jaggery.

facts.text: Producer defined in section 2(p) as person who produces etc. agricultural produce, not being one who works as trader, broker etc.

anchor.surface_text: By section 2 p  producer means a person who, whether by himself or through hired labour, produces, rears or catches, any agricultural produce, number being a producer who also works as a trader, broker or Dalal, companymission agent or Arhatiya or who is otherwise ordinarily engaged in the business, of storage of agricultural produce.

facts.text: Trader defined in section 2(y) as person engaged in buying or selling agricultural produce as principal or agent, includes processor

anchor.surface_text: By section 2 y  trader means a person who in the ordinary companyrse of business is engaged in buying or selling agricultural produce as a principal or as a duly authorised agent of one or more principals and includes a person, engaged in processing of agricultural produce.

facts.text: No person shall carry on business as trader etc. in Market Yard without licence from Committee (section 9(2))

anchor.surface_text: Section 9 2  which is material for our purpose, may be quoted- No person shall, in a Principal Market Yard or any Sub-Market Yard, carry on business or work as a trader, broker, companymission-agent, warehouse man, weighman, palledar or in such other capacity as may be prescribed in respect of any specified agricultural produce except under and- in accordance with the companyditions of a licence obtained therefore from the Committee companycerned.

facts.text: Market Committee constituted under section 13 with representatives from different sources including 10 producers (8 elected, 2 SC nominated)

anchor.surface_text: Section 13 provides for companystitution of the Market Committee and provides for representation from different sources as detailed in  i  to  xi  thereunder. ... whereby ten representatives of the producers are included in the Committee. ... under section 13 1  vii , 8 producers are elected. ... section 13 1  vii-a , which was introduced by an amendment in 1970, two producers belonging to the scheduled castes

facts.text: Committee has power to issue/renew/refuse/suspend/cancel licences under section 17

anchor.surface_text: Under section 17, A Committee shall, for the purposes of this Act, have the powers to- issue or renew licences under this Act on such terms and companyditions and subject to such restrictions as may be prescribed, or, after recording reasons therefore, refuse to issue or renew any such licence suspend or cancel licences issued or renewed under this Act.

facts.text: Appeals against Committee orders to Director of Agriculture (section 25), revision by State Government (section 32)

anchor.surface_text: Section 25 provides for appeals against the, orders of the Committee to the Director of Agriculture who is to decide the same in accordance with the rules. Under section 32, the State Government also has powers of revision and may call for the records of the proceedings of the Committee and pass orders modifying, annulling or reversing the same.

facts.text: Rule 70(4)(i): Committee may issue licence if satisfied applicant is solvent and desirable person

anchor.surface_text: Rule 70 4   i  may number be quoted On receipt of such application together with the amount of fee prescribed under rule 67, the Market Committee may issue him the licence applied for,, if-  a  it is satisfied that the applicant is solvent  b  it is satisfied that the applicant is a desirable person to whom a licence may be granted

facts.text: Petitioners claim rule 70(4) lays down vague criteria (solvency and desirability)

anchor.surface_text: The Act in the matter of grant of licences gives numberguidance at all and even under rule 70 4  two vague criteria have been laid down in the matter of issue of licences under the Act.

facts.text: Rule 76(1): Every consignment of specified agricultural produce brought for sale shall be sold by open auction (except retail sales)

anchor.surface_text: Rule 76 1  which is impugned may be quoted Every companysignment of specified agricultural produce brought for sale into the Principal Market Yard or any sub-Market Yard shall be sold by open auction Provided that numberhing in this sub-rule shall apply to a retail sale as may be specified in the bye-laws of the Committee.

facts.text: Previous similar Acts of Madras, Bombay, Gujarat upheld by Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: Some provisions of similar Acts of the States of Madras, Bombay and Gujarat had earlier been the targets of unsuccessful attack in this Court ... See M. V S. Arunchala Nadar etc. v. The State of Madras others 1  Mohammad Hussain Gulam Mohammad and Another v. The State of Bombay and another 2  and Jan Mohammed Noor Mohammed Begban v. State of Gujarat and Another 3

facts.text: Court holds no perpetual majority of producers in Committee, first submission fails

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the first submission, as earlier numbered, the grievance is number factually accurate. Out of 23 members of. the Committee only 10 are from the producers. Therefore, there is numberquestion of a perpetual majority of the producers in the Committee.

facts.text: Court holds entrustment of licensing to Committee not prejudicial or unreasonable

anchor.surface_text: We find it difficult to appreciate how the performance of this duty by the Committee will at all prejudice the traders. ... That would, however, number make, the, provision invalid number can it be said to place an unreasonable restriction on the right of the petitioners to trade.

facts.text: Court holds sufficient guidance in Act for licensing, criteria not vague

anchor.surface_text: This submission fails to take numbere of the fact that the Committee which is entrusted with the duty of granting licences companysists of people from different sources vitally interested in the marketing of agricultural produce. ... we cannot accede to the submission that the two criteria taken with the other guidelines from the provisions of the Act and the rules offer numberproper guidance

facts.text: Petitioners required to provide storage space to producers

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners are required to provide a storage space to the producers for their agricultural produce going to the market and this obligation is also an unreasonable res- triction on the fundamental right of the petitioners.

facts.text: Court holds storage obligation not unreasonable, subject to fees under rules

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the fourth submission, it is sufficient to point out that under section 16 2  vii  the Committee has to provide, inter alia, accommodation for storage ... There is, therefore, numbersubstance in the fourth submission of the petitioner.

facts.text: Court holds rule 76(1) within rule-making power under section 40, not unreasonable restriction

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the last submission regarding invalidity of rule 76 1 , we are number satisfied that the same is ultra vires section 40 of the Act. ... There is, therefore, numbersubstance in the submission that rule 76 1  violates the fundamental right of the petitioners under Article 19  1   g  of the Constitution.

facts.text: All writ applications fail and are dismissed

anchor.surface_text: In the result all the applications fail and are dismissed.
Art. 32 of the Constitution of India
Article 32 of the Constitution
Article 14

issues.text: Whether the Uttar Pradesh Krishi Utpadan Mandi Adhiniyam, 1964 and the rules made thereunder violate Article 14 and Article 19(1)(g) of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: Article 32 of the Constitution... Article 19 1  g  of the, Constitution. The petitioners in all the above cases are traders or commission agents dealing in agricultural produce. The following submissions are made on behalf of the petitioners The constitution of the Market Committee under section 13 of the Act is highly prejudicial

issues.text: Whether the constitution of the Market Committee under section 13 of the Act provides a perpetual majority of producers making it prejudicial to traders and entrustment of licensing powers to it an unreasonable restriction on the right to trade?

anchor.surface_text: The constitution of the Market Committee under section 13 of the Act is highly prejudicial to their interests and of the traders in general since, it will have a perpetual majority of producers. To entrustment of licensing to such a Market Committee instead of to any impartial authority is unfair and an un-. reasonable restriction on the right to trade.

issues.text: Whether the Act provides no guidance for grant of licences and rule 70(4) lays down vague criteria for issuing licences violating Articles 14 and 19(1)(g)?

anchor.surface_text: The Act in the matter of grant of licences gives no guidance at all and even under rule 70 4 two vague criteria have been laid down in the matter of issue of licences under the Act.

issues.text: Whether the obligation on petitioners to provide storage space to producers is an unreasonable restriction on fundamental right to trade or business under Article 19(1)(g)?

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners are required to provide a storage space to the producers for their agricultural produce going to the market and this obligation is also an unreasonable res- triction on the fundamental right of the petitioners.

issues.text: Whether rule 76(1) is ultra vires section 40 of the Act and imposes unreasonable restrictions on the right to carry on trade or business under Article 19(1)(g)?

anchor.surface_text: Rule 76 1 is invalid and ultra vires section 40 of the Act and has also placed unreasonable restrictions on the right to carry on trade or business.

arguments.claim: Constitution of the Market Committee under section 13 prejudicial to traders' interests due to perpetual majority of producers

anchor.surface_text: The constitution of the Market Committee under section 13 of the Act is highly prejudicial to their interests and of the traders in general since, it will have a perpetual majority of producers.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: reby ten representatives of the producers are included in the Committee. It is pointed out by the learned Solicitor General and number companytradicte

arguments.court_reasoning: Only 10 out of 23 members from producers; no perpetual majority; reasonable scheme with elections and nominations

arguments.claim: Market Committee under section 13 consists of 23 members out of which ten are from the producers

anchor.surface_text: It is pointed out by the learned Solicitor General and not contradicted by Mr. Sen that the Committee under section 13 consists of 23 members out of which ten are from the producers.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: reby ten representatives of the producers are included in the Committee. It is pointed out by the learned Solicitor General and number companytradicte

arguments.court_reasoning: Factual accuracy accepted; grievance not valid

arguments.claim: Entrustment of licensing powers to the Market Committee instead of impartial authority is unfair and unreasonable restriction on right to trade

anchor.surface_text: To entrustment of licensing to such a Market Committee instead of to any impartial authority is unfair and an unreasonable restriction on the right to trade.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: sides performing other functions. Form No. XI in which a trader has to submit his application for a licence. also gives various particulars from which

arguments.court_reasoning: No prejudice shown; hypothetical as no licences refused; Committee can exercise impartially; not unreasonable

arguments.claim: Act provides no guidance for grant of licences and rule 70(4) lays down vague criteria (solvency, desirability)

anchor.surface_text: The Act in the matter of grant of licences gives no guidance at all and even under rule 70 4 two vague criteria have been laid down in the matter of issue of licences under the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: is submitted that the choice of the two criteria under rule 70 4   i  is bad and there is numberproper guidance in these criteria which are number ca

arguments.court_reasoning: Sufficient guidance from preamble, s.16 duties, forms, licence conditions, diverse Committee, appeals s.25, revision s.32, speaking orders; criteria objective with context

arguments.claim: Requirement for petitioners (traders) to provide storage space to producers is unreasonable restriction on fundamental right

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners are required to provide a storage space to the producers for their agricultural produce going to the market and this obligation is also an unreasonable restriction on the fundamental right of the petitioners.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: w rule 76 1  which is within the rule making power can be said to be unreasonable. In order that the producers obtain the best price for their company

arguments.court_reasoning: Committee must provide storage under s.16(2)(vii); trader storage interim and subject to fees under rule 52(4)

arguments.claim: Rule 76(1) mandating open auction sales is ultra vires section 40 and imposes unreasonable restriction on trade

anchor.surface_text: Rule 76 1 is invalid and ultra vires section 40 of the Act and has also placed unreasonable restrictions on the right to carry on trade or business.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: le in their transactions and, as a necessary companycomitant, eliminated the mode of private sale by individual negotiations resulting in malpractices

arguments.court_reasoning: Within rule-making power s.40(2)(xxvii); prescribes mode of sale under s.9(2)/17; ensures best price for producers, eliminates malpractices; proviso for retail; not unreasonable

arguments.claim: Provisions of similar market regulation Acts in Madras, Bombay, Gujarat upheld by this Court

anchor.surface_text: Some provisions of similar Acts of the States of Madras, Bombay and Gujarat had earlier been the targets of unsuccessful attack in this Court ... See M. V S. Arunchala Nadar etc. v. The State of Madras others 1  Mohammad Hussain Gulam Mohammad and Another v. The State of Bombay and another 2  and Jan Mohammed Noor Mohammed Begban v. State of Gujarat and Another 3

arguments.claim: Entrustment of licensing to Committee not prejudicial or unreasonable as it represents diverse interests and no refusals occurred

anchor.surface_text: We find it difficult to appreciate how the performance of this duty by the Committee will at all prejudice the traders. ... That would, however, not make, the, provision invalid nor can it be said to place an unreasonable restriction on the right of the petitioners to trade.

arguments.claim: Sufficient guidance for licensing from Act's preamble, objects, s.16 functions, diverse Committee composition, appeals, revisions, speaking orders

anchor.surface_text: This submission fails to take note of the fact that the Committee which is entrusted with the duty of granting licences consists of people from different sources vitally interested in the marketing of agricultural produce. ... we cannot accede to the submission that the two criteria taken with the other guidelines from the provisions of the Act and the rules offer no proper guidance

arguments.claim: Storage obligation not unreasonable as Committee provides facilities under s.16(2)(vii) and storage fees applicable under rule 52(4)

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the fourth submission, it is sufficient to point out that under section 16 2 vii the Committee has to provide, inter alia, accommodation for storage ... There is, therefore, no substance in the fourth submission of the petitioner.

arguments.claim: Rule 76(1) not ultra vires s.40 as it implements purposes via mode of sale for producers' benefit

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the last submission regarding invalidity of rule 76 1 , we are not satisfied that the same is ultra vires section 40 of the Act. ... There is, therefore, no substance in the submission that rule 76 1 violates the fundamental right of the petitioners under Article 19 1 g of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Lala Hari Chand case distinguishable: no appeal or standards there unlike here

anchor.surface_text: This decision is clearly distinguishable from the present case. In that case there was no right of appeal to any superior authority against a refusal to grant or renew a licence and the non-tribal trader had no remedy whatsoever against such an order. This Court also observed in that case that a perusal of the Regulation shows that it nowhere provides any principle or standard on which the Executive Committee has to act in granting or refusing to grant the licence

arguments.claim: Harakchand (Gold Control) distinguishable: vague criteria like 'suitability' there unlike solvency/desirability here with guidance

anchor.surface_text: The second decision, is in Harakchand Ratanchand Benthia... This is not the same thing as the suitability simpliciter which this Court had to deal with in the Gold Control Act case. The decision is, therefore, clearly distinguishable.

holdings.text: The constitution of the Market Committee under section 13 does not result in a perpetual majority of producers and the scheme of representation is reasonable.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the first submission, as earlier numbered, the grievance is number factually accurate. Out of 23 members of. the Committee only 10 are from the producers. Therefore, there is numberquestion of a perpetual majority of the producers in the Committee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual composition is 10 producers out of 23 members; 8 elected, 2 nominated from SC; no unreasonable features; first submission of no avail.

holdings.text: Entrustment of licensing powers to the Market Committee is not prejudicial to traders or an unreasonable restriction on trade.

anchor.surface_text: We find it difficult to appreciate how the performance of this duty by the Committee will at all prejudice the traders. ... That would, however, number make, the, provision invalid number can it be said to place an unreasonable restriction on the right of the petitioners to trade.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Committee represents diverse interests; no licences refused to petitioners (hypothetical); can exercise impartially; not unreasonable.

holdings.text: The Act provides sufficient guidance for grant of licences; criteria of solvency and desirability under rule 70(4)(i) are not vague.

anchor.surface_text: This submission fails to take numbere of the fact that the Committee which is entrusted with the duty of granting licences companysists of people from different sources vitally interested in the marketing of agricultural produce. ... we cannot accede to the submission that the two criteria taken with the other guidelines from the provisions of the Act and the rules offer numberproper guidance

holdings.reasoning_summary: Guidance from preamble, s.16 duties, forms, licence conditions, diverse composition, appeals (s.25), revision (s.32), speaking orders; criteria objective in context.

holdings.text: Obligation to provide storage space to producers is not an unreasonable restriction.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the fourth submission, it is sufficient to point out that under section 16 2  vii  the Committee has to provide, inter alia, accommodation for storage ... There is, therefore, numbersubstance in the fourth submission of the petitioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Committee obligated to provide storage under s.16(2)(vii); trader storage interim and subject to fees under rule 52(4).

holdings.text: Rule 76(1) is not ultra vires section 40 and does not impose unreasonable restriction under Article 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the last submission regarding invalidity of rule 76 1 , we are number satisfied that the same is ultra vires section 40 of the Act. ... There is, therefore, numbersubstance in the submission that rule 76 1  violates the fundamental right of the petitioners under Article 19  1   g  of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Within rule-making power s.40(2)(xxvii); prescribes mode of sale under ss.9(2)/17; ensures best price, eliminates malpractices; proviso for retail sales.

holdings.text: The Uttar Pradesh Krishi Utpadan Mandi Adhiniyam, 1964 as amended and rules thereunder do not violate Articles 14 and 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: Goswami, J.-By the above writ applications under Article 32 of the Constitution the validity of the Uttar Pradesh Krishi Utpadhan Mandi Adhiniyam, 1964  U.P. Act No. XXV of 1964 as amended by U.P. Act No. 10 of 1970   briefly called the Act  and the rules made thereunder are challenged on the ground of violation of Article 14 and Article 19 1  g  of the, Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All specific challenges rejected; similar prior Acts upheld; provisions reasonable for protecting producers and regulating markets.

holdings.text: Lala Hari Chand Sarda v. Mizo District Council is distinguishable as no appeal or standards there unlike here.

anchor.surface_text: This decision is clearly distinguishable from the present case. In that case there was no right of appeal to any superior authority against a refusal to grant or renew a licence and the non-tribal trader had no remedy whatsoever against such an order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Here, appeals under s.25, revision s.32, standards/guidance present; speaking orders required.

holdings.text: Harakchand Ratanchand Benthia (Gold Control) is distinguishable; solvency/desirability not same as vague 'suitability'.

anchor.surface_text: The second decision, is in Harakchand Ratanchand Benthia... This is not the same thing as the suitability simpliciter which this Court had to deal with in the Gold Control Act case. The decision is, therefore, clearly distinguishable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Criteria here objective with Act's guidance; not vague like Gold Control's 'suitability', 'public interest'.

precedents.citation: M. V S. Arunchala Nadar etc. v. The State of Madras others 1

precedents.citation: Lala Hari Chand Sarda v. Mizo District Council and Anr. 1

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen particularly drew our attention to two decisions of this Court. The first is given in Lala Hari Chand Sarda v. Mizo District Council and Anr.  1  That was a case where the Executive Committee of the Mizo District Council refused to renew the temporary licence issued to the appellant therein who was a number-tribal trader under section 3 of the Lushai Hills District  Trading by number-Tribals  Regulation, 1953.

precedents.case_name: Lala Hari Chand Sarda v. Mizo District Council
precedents.cited_proposition: licensing provision invalid due to lack of guidance, standards, and appeal mechanism violating Article 19(1)(g)
precedents.cited_holding: section 3 struck down as violative of Article 19(1)(g) for no right of appeal and no principle or standard for granting/refusing licence

precedents.citation: Harakchand Ratanchana Benthia and Ors. etc. v. Union of India and Ors. 1

anchor.surface_text: The second decision, is in Harakchand Ratanchana Benthia and Ors. etc. v. Union of India and Ors.  1  This was a case under the Gold  Control  Act and Mr. Sen drew our attention to the expression suitability of the applicant in section 27 6  e  of the Gold  Control  Act which was held to provide numberobjective standard or numberm and as such was held to be companystitutionally invalid.

precedents.case_name: Harakchand Ratanchand Benthia v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: vague criteria like 'suitability of the applicant', 'anticipated demand', etc., in licensing provisions lack objective standards violating Article 19(1)(g)
precedents.cited_holding: clauses (a), (b), (e) and (g) of section 27(6) of Gold Control Act held constitutionally invalid for lacking objective standards

anchor.surface_text: In the result all the applications fail and are dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: All writ petitions under Article 32 dismissed; validity of the Act and rules upheld

Act No. XXV of 1964 as amended by U.P. Act No. 10 of 1970   briefly called the Act  and the rules made thereunder are challenged on the ground of violation of Article 14 and Article 19 1  g  of the, Constitution.
